ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really shaped my writing skills as a whole. Professor Riley helped tremendously with my style and word choice.
I learned how to closely read non-fiction essays, and developed skills to be able to write compelling essays of my own.

I learned how to better write personal essays, use descriptive language, write creative non-fiction, and read creative non-fiction for craft. I also was exposed to a lot of great writers that I'm looking to read more beyond this course.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Riley is great. The class discussions of the essays we read, which were all excellent, were engaging and yielded good insights. Essay assignments were fun, appropriately challenging, and we received clear and useful feedback on all of our drafts.

Weaknesses: Not many that I can think of! Sometimes it could be challenging to finish readings in time for class, but not more so than any other seminar.

I think organizing essays and their respective themes by unit made it easy to expect upcoming pieces, and made for easy comparisons/contrasts. Perhaps the time in between editing essays was too little (generally you had a week to submit a polished draft, and about 3-4 days to submit a final draft after receiving revisions, and for me personally, I am a perfectionist, so a polished draft was almost never good enough for me), but Prof. Riley was very kind about allowing students more time if necessary.

I think the essay format works. The workshopping process is fairly productive and fun. I like how there's no final or midterm, and I think they would detract from the class as a whole. The regular schedule of writing essays and receiving feedback both kept me engaged and kept my writing skills up. I think this course could improve by using class time differently. I felt discussing the readings only netted so much discussion, and that class time could be used better.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100%. This class should be mandatory for students who plan to take more writing classes
Yes this a great creative writing class
Yes! It's fun, meaningful, and you come away having read many excellent essays and written a few yourself.
I absolutely would recommend English 114 to a fellow student! It is chock-full of exciting and engaging material, and you will walk away from it grateful for all of the exposure.

I would definitely recommend this course. It was fun and fairly easy, but it still demanded a baseline of engagement. The readings are fun, and the work for the class is even better: you literally just write four personal essays. You can be creative in rewarding ways.
